artists.artist: Related to AP-object 4, though of inferior craftsmanship (?)

dcomments.dcomment: A modified, later copy of crown AP-object 4.

txstates.txstate: Dark tinge and slightly tarnished from time.

details.detail: Elaborate silver ceremonial crown in a tiered domed shape with cross finial. Three-tiered structure with small ornamental fringe bells, mirroring a church dome in design. One halfmoon-shaped lip protruding from lowest tier. Ornate decorations and depictions of Biblical Scenes as well as Saints on lowest tier. Depictions include: Crucifixion (facing the lip), a riding warrior saint (St. Mercurios or Theodor the Oriental), a saint riding a lion (St. Mamas or St. Samuˀel), Gäbrä Mäsqäl, the Virgin with Child, an Angel, St. George slaying the Dragon and saving Birutawit, St. Säble (?) with the symbols of the Evangelists, a female saint, Birds of Paradise (on lip). Lowest tier solid silver with knot and crisscross etching. Middle part of the vertical connectors with filled with strapwork / interlaced bands, upper part solid with etchings in geometric knot designs. Uppermost part solid half-round with small moving elements. One medium-sized lozenge-shaped cross finial with strapwork and a Greek cross centre element in cutout relief. The crown is obviously a "mirror object" for AP-object 4, however, it is of lower craftsmanship, particularly visible in the execution of the strapwork and the etching of the narrative scenes. In direct comparison between AP-4 and AP-5, the depictions on AP-5 deviate in key elements from Biblical Scenes carefully etched into AP-4: The Angels behind Mary and the Child are missing entirely, the cartouche for “qəddus Säble” has been moved while the cartouches for Gäbrä Mänfäs Qəddus and one armed Angel are missing entirely; a warrior saint and a female saint have been added. This indicates that AP-5 is a later, modified copy of AP-4, a finding also substantiated by the heavy Second Gondarine style employed in AP-5. Lastly, state of preservation of AP-5 is better than that of AP-4, indicating that AP-4 enjoyed heavier use or is indeed an older Vorlage.
